instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the ML models, and how far can this metric go in determining the accuracy of leaf nitrogen estimation?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the ML models in the related study was the coefficient of determination (R-2). This metric measures the proportion of the variance in the dependent variable (leaf %N content in this case) that can be explained by the independent variables (spectral data and vegetation indices). 

The coefficient of determination (R-2) can provide an indication of how well the ML models are able to predict leaf %N content based on the input variables. An R-2 value of 1 indicates a perfect fit, meaning that all the variance in the dependent variable can be explained by the independent variables. On the other hand, an R-2 value of 0 indicates that the independent variables have no explanatory power in predicting the dependent variable.

In the related study, the ML models achieved an R-2 value of about 80% for the different categories of variables. This suggests that the ML models were able to explain approximately 80% of the variance in leaf %N content using the spectral data and vegetation indices. Therefore, the R-2 metric can provide a good measure of the accuracy of leaf nitrogen estimation, indicating how well the ML models are able to predict leaf %N content based on the input variables.

instruction: How did the study compare the performance of vegetation indices and spectral wavelengths in leaf nitrogen estimation in corn?
Output: The study compared the performance of vegetation indices (VIs) and spectral wavelengths in leaf nitrogen estimation in corn by analyzing 26 VIs and five spectral bands obtained from a red-edge multispectral sensor mounted on an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV). The objective was to determine if combinations of VIs substantially improved the results compared to the original spectral data. The results showed that adding VIs to the spectral bands improved the estimation of leaf nitrogen content in corn. The combination of SCCCI, NDRE, and red-edge had the largest coefficient of determination (R-2) compared to the other categories of variables used in predicting leaf nitrogen content in corn.
